input_text.Prompt:
The Super Bowl seems to be just about the only time anyone is actually excited about commercials, and TV network execs are well aware of it. NBC has taken yet another step away from ad-saturated air time with its announcement today that it will broadcast Saturday Night Live next season with 30 percent fewer commercials.

For viewers, this should be a welcome change; it means two entire commercial pods being cut out. In their place, viewers can expect to see more program content, albeit some sponsored by advertisers. SNL is no stranger to branded sketches, though, so at least it doesn't sound like the audience will be blindsided by an unfamiliar form of advertising.

The late-night show's linear ratings have been on the decline in recent years, as Deadline points out, even as skits continue to be popular online. Cutting down on commercial break time is one way the network hopes to bring viewers' eyes back to live broadcasts. The show is called Saturday Night Live, after all.

"As the decades have gone by, commercial time has grown," said Lorne Michaels, SNL creator and executive producer, in a statement. "This will give time back to the show and make it easier to watch the show live."

NBC has been looking to experiment with advertising lately. The SNL switch-up comes just days after the network revealed that June's two-hour Aquarius season 2 premiere would be broadcast commercial-free. The NBCUniversal subsidiary isn't alone, either. Multiple major media and entertainment companies have been forced to readjust their ad strategies as audiences look to ad-free options like Netflix, Amazon Instant Video, and others.

It's hard not to get excited as a viewer, but you can bet that network execs are feeling some pressure. It's up to them to find their ideal balance between making audiences happy and bringing in revenue.

Editors' Recommendations

Generate a summary:
input_text.Response A: NBC has announced that it will air Saturday Night Live (SNL) without commercials next season, in an attempt to increase the show's ratings. The network will also cut back on advertising during its other shows, including the forthcoming new series, This Is Us. The move is part of a wider strategy to improve NBC's overall ratings. However, the move will also put the network at risk, as it will have to make up for the loss of advertising revenue. NBC's average advertising revenue was $1.6bn in 2016, according to research by the New York Times. NBC's chief executive, Alex profiles, said, "As the decades have gone by, commercial time has grown." "This will give time back to the show and make it easier to watch the show live."
input_text.Response B: NBC will broadcast Saturday Night Live next season with 30% fewer commercials. This will give more time to the show and make it easier to watch live.

input_text.Prompt:
Given the document below, determine if the summary is factually consistent with the document. 
Document: Editor's Note: Sign up for Unlocking the World, CNN Travel's weekly newsletter. Get news about destinations opening, inspiration for future adventures, plus the latest in aviation, food and drink, where to stay and other travel developments.

CNN --

For years, journey times flying east from Israel depended on who you were flying with.

If you were boarding a flight operated by Israeli airlines, including national carrier El Al, your flight would take around two hours more than if you were flying with another airline.

The reason? Israeli airlines were banned from the airspace of both Oman and Saudi Arabia. That meant flights to India and Southeast Asia, which would naturally head east from Israel, had to dip south, crossing over Jordan and following the Red Sea down to the bottom of the Arabian Peninsula, before hooking northeast.

Now, all that is set to change. Following the Saudi government's announcement in July 2022 that the country's airspace would open up to all carriers, Oman has followed suit.

El Al has posted a map of their current and new routes to Southeast Asia From El Al Israel

On February 23, the Civil Aviation Authority of Oman announced that it will open its airspace to "all carriers that meet the requirements of the Authority for overflying" - effectively ending the ban on El Al, Israir and Arkia, Israel's three airlines.

In a tweet, it said the move was "part of the Sultanate of Oman's continuous efforts to fulfil its obligations under the Chicago Convention of 1944, which stipulates non-discrimination between civil aircrafts used in international air navigation."

The move could cut Israeli carriers' flight times to Asia by up to three hours, Jonathan Sivarajah, an El Al frequent flier and Israeli aviation commentator, told CNN.

As part of the Sultanate of Oman's continuous efforts to fulfill its obligations under the Chicago Convention of 1944, the Civil Aviation Authority affirms that the Sultanate's airspace is open for all carriers that meet the requirements of the Authority for overflyuing. pic.twitter.com/jNaqqDxZM1 -- hyy'@ lTWyrn lmdny (@CAAOMN) February 23, 2023

He added that it "opens up further opportunities [for the airlines], not only to Asia but potentially to Australia, too."

El Al's nonstop flight from Tel Aviv to Bangkok is currently listed as taking 10 hours 45 minutes. But a nonstop flight on Royal Jordanian from Amman - 100 miles east of Tel Aviv - takes eight hours 10 minutes. In fact, flying Tel Aviv to Amman, and then on to Bangkok can be quicker, even including transfer time at the airport - a connecting flight can take as little as nine hours 55 minutes on Royal Jordanian.

When the airline was banned from Saudi airspace, El Al flights from Tel Aviv to Mumbai took seven hours 45 minutes. That flight time was then slashed to five hours 15 minutes, before the route was put on hold.

As the announcement was made, El Al swiftly posted a map of their old and new routes to Southeast Asia on Instagram.

Sivarajah said that until now, competing international carriers have "flooded" Israel with quicker flights than what the country's own airlines were able to provide.

"Tel Aviv-bound foreign carriers such as Air India could operate over territory which El Al couldn't. There was a significant fare difference because of the routing in favor of the likes of Air India," he said.

"It wasn't until the Abraham Accords [of 2020] and the Saudi approval that it became partly possible for Israeli carriers to compete. The last stumbling block was Oman."

He expects the new routings to start "within the next few days."

In a statement, Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called it "a day of great news for Israeli aviation."

He added: "The Far East is not so far away and the skies are no longer the limit.

"We have worked to open the airspace, first over Saudi Arabia, and from 2018 when I visited Oman, to add Oman as well, so that we can fly directly to India and on to Australia. This was achieved today, after considerable effort, including in recent months. Here is good news - Israel is opening up to the east on an unprecedented scale."

Israel's Foreign Minister Eli Cohen also released a statement, calling the news "a historic decision that will shorten the road to Asia, lower costs for Israeli citizens and help Israeli airlines to be more competitive." He personally thanked the sultan of Oman, Haitham bin Tariq al-Said, for his "substantial help" in the process.

The announcement came after months of talks between the two countries.

It also follows an announcement earlier this month that El Al would start a frequent flier partnership with UAE carrier Etihad Airways. Frequent fliers can now collect and spend air miles across both airlines. The two had started codesharing on flights in 2021.

Last year, El Al said that a route from Tel Aviv to Melbourne, Australia, was in the works.
Summary: Oman is opening up its airspace to Iranian carriers, including Iran Air. Previously, the airlines had to fly a roundabout route to parts of Asia, adding hours to journey times.
Is the summary consistent with the document? First provide detailed reasoning, then answer "Yes" or "No".
Reasoning:
input_text.Response A:
The summary is inconsistent with the given document because the document discusses the opening of Omani airspace to Israeli airlines, not Iranian carriers. Additionally, the document mentions that the new routing will shorten the journey to Asia, not to Australia.
No
input_text.Response B: Yes

Document: Editor's Note: Sign up for Unlocking the World, CNN Travel's weekly newsletter. Get news about destinations opening, inspiration for future adventures, plus the latest in aviation, food and drink, where to stay and other travel developments.

CNN --

For years, journey times flying east from Israel depended on who you were flying with.

If you were boarding a flight operated by Israeli airlines, including national carrier El Al, your flight would take around two hours more than if you were flying with another airline.

The reason? Israeli airlines were banned from the airspace of both Oman and Saudi Arabia. That meant flights to India and Southeast Asia, which would naturally head east from Israel, had to dip south, crossing over Jordan and following the Red Sea down to the bottom of the Arabian Peninsula, before hooking northeast.

Now, all that is set to change. Following the Saudi government's announcement in July 2022 that the country's airspace would open up to all carriers, Oman has followed suit.

El Al has posted a map of their current and new routes to Southeast Asia From El Al Israel

On February 23, the Civil Aviation Authority of Oman announced that it will open its airspace to "all carriers that meet the requirements of the Authority for overflying" - effectively ending the ban on El Al, Israir and Arkia, Israel's three airlines.

In a tweet, it said the move was "part of the Sultanate of Oman's continuous efforts to fulfil its obligations under the Chicago Convention of 1944, which stipulates non-discrimination between civil aircrafts used in international air navigation."

The move could cut Israeli carriers' flight times to Asia by up to three hours, Jonathan Sivarajah, an El Al frequent flier and Israeli aviation commentator, told CNN.

As part of the Sultanate of Oman's continuous efforts to fulfill its obligations under the Chicago Convention of 1944, the Civil Aviation Authority affirms that the Sultanate's airspace is open for all carriers that meet the requirements of the Authority for overflyuing. pic.twitter.com/jNaqqDxZM1 -- hyy'@ lTWyrn lmdny (@CAAOMN) February 23, 2023

He added that it "opens up further opportunities [for the airlines], not only to Asia but potentially to Australia, too."

El Al's nonstop flight from Tel Aviv to Bangkok is currently listed as taking 10 hours 45 minutes. But a nonstop flight on Royal Jordanian from Amman - 100 miles east of Tel Aviv - takes eight hours 10 minutes. In fact, flying Tel Aviv to Amman, and then on to Bangkok can be quicker, even including transfer time at the airport - a connecting flight can take as little as nine hours 55 minutes on Royal Jordanian.

When the airline was banned from Saudi airspace, El Al flights from Tel Aviv to Mumbai took seven hours 45 minutes. That flight time was then slashed to five hours 15 minutes, before the route was put on hold.

As the announcement was made, El Al swiftly posted a map of their old and new routes to Southeast Asia on Instagram.

Sivarajah said that until now, competing international carriers have "flooded" Israel with quicker flights than what the country's own airlines were able to provide.

"Tel Aviv-bound foreign carriers such as Air India could operate over territory which El Al couldn't. There was a significant fare difference because of the routing in favor of the likes of Air India," he said.

"It wasn't until the Abraham Accords [of 2020] and the Saudi approval that it became partly possible for Israeli carriers to compete. The last stumbling block was Oman."

He expects the new routings to start "within the next few days."

In a statement, Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called it "a day of great news for Israeli aviation."

He added: "The Far East is not so far away and the skies are no longer the limit.

"We have worked to open the airspace, first over Saudi Arabia, and from 2018 when I visited Oman, to add Oman as well, so that we can fly directly to India and on to Australia. This was achieved today, after considerable effort, including in recent months. Here is good news - Israel is opening up to the east on an unprecedented scale."

Israel's Foreign Minister Eli Cohen also released a statement, calling the news "a historic decision that will shorten the road to Asia, lower costs for Israeli citizens and help Israeli airlines to be more competitive." He personally thanked the sultan of Oman, Haitham bin Tariq al-Said, for his "substantial help" in the process.

The announcement came after months of talks between the two countries.

It also follows an announcement earlier this month that El Al would start a frequent flier partnership with UAE carrier Etihad Airways. Frequent fliers can now collect and spend air miles across both airlines. The two had started codesharing on flights in 2021.

Last year, El Al said that a route from Tel Aviv to Melbourne, Australia, was in the works.
Summary: Oman is opening up its airspace to Iranian carriers, including Iran Air. Previously, the airlines had to fly a roundabout route to parts of Asia, adding hours to journey times.
Is the summary consistent with the document? First provide detailed reasoning, then answer "Yes" or "No".
Reasoning:
input_text.Response A: Yes
input_text.Response B:
The summary is not consistent with the document, which discusses the opening of Oman's airspace to all carriers that meet the requirements of the Authority for overflying, not to Iranian carriers specifically.
No

NBC has taken yet another step away from ad-saturated air time with its announcement today that it will broadcast Saturday Night Live next season with 30 percent fewer commercials.

For viewers, this should be a welcome change; it means two entire commercial pods being cut out. In their place, viewers can expect to see more program content, albeit some sponsored by advertisers. SNL is no stranger to branded sketches, though, so at least it doesn't sound like the audience will be blindsided by an unfamiliar form of advertising.

The late-night show's linear ratings have been on the decline in recent years, as Deadline points out, even as skits continue to be popular online. Cutting down on commercial break time is one way the network hopes to bring viewers' eyes back to live broadcasts. The show is called Saturday Night Live, after all.

NBC has been looking to experiment with advertising lately. Multiple major media and entertainment companies have been forced to readjust their ad strategies as audiences look to ad-free options like Netflix, Amazon Instant Video, and others.

It's hard not to get excited as a viewer, but you can bet that network execs are feeling some pressure. It's up to them to find their ideal balance between making audiences happy and bringing in revenue.

input_text.Prompt:
Given the document below, determine if the summary is factually consistent with the document. 
Document: Editor's Note: Sign up for Unlocking the World, CNN Travel's weekly newsletter. Get news about destinations opening, inspiration for future adventures, plus the latest in aviation, food and drink, where to stay and other travel developments.

CNN --

For years, journey times flying east from Israel depended on who you were flying with.

If you were boarding a flight operated by Israeli airlines, including national carrier El Al, your flight would take around two hours more than if you were flying with another airline.

The reason? Israeli airlines were banned from the airspace of both Oman and Saudi Arabia. That meant flights to India and Southeast Asia, which would naturally head east from Israel, had to dip south, crossing over Jordan and following the Red Sea down to the bottom of the Arabian Peninsula, before hooking northeast.

Now, all that is set to change. Following the Saudi government's announcement in July 2022 that the country's airspace would open up to all carriers, Oman has followed suit.

El Al has posted a map of their current and new routes to Southeast Asia From El Al Israel

On February 23, the Civil Aviation Authority of Oman announced that it will open its airspace to "all carriers that meet the requirements of the Authority for overflying" - effectively ending the ban on El Al, Israir and Arkia, Israel's three airlines.

In a tweet, it said the move was "part of the Sultanate of Oman's continuous efforts to fulfil its obligations under the Chicago Convention of 1944, which stipulates non-discrimination between civil aircrafts used in international air navigation."

The move could cut Israeli carriers' flight times to Asia by up to three hours, Jonathan Sivarajah, an El Al frequent flier and Israeli aviation commentator, told CNN.

As part of the Sultanate of Oman's continuous efforts to fulfill its obligations under the Chicago Convention of 1944, the Civil Aviation Authority affirms that the Sultanate's airspace is open for all carriers that meet the requirements of the Authority for overflyuing. pic.twitter.com/jNaqqDxZM1 -- hyy'@ lTWyrn lmdny (@CAAOMN) February 23, 2023

He added that it "opens up further opportunities [for the airlines], not only to Asia but potentially to Australia, too."

El Al's nonstop flight from Tel Aviv to Bangkok is currently listed as taking 10 hours 45 minutes. But a nonstop flight on Royal Jordanian from Amman - 100 miles east of Tel Aviv - takes eight hours 10 minutes. In fact, flying Tel Aviv to Amman, and then on to Bangkok can be quicker, even including transfer time at the airport - a connecting flight can take as little as nine hours 55 minutes on Royal Jordanian.

When the airline was banned from Saudi airspace, El Al flights from Tel Aviv to Mumbai took seven hours 45 minutes. That flight time was then slashed to five hours 15 minutes, before the route was put on hold.

As the announcement was made, El Al swiftly posted a map of their old and new routes to Southeast Asia on Instagram.

Sivarajah said that until now, competing international carriers have "flooded" Israel with quicker flights than what the country's own airlines were able to provide.

"Tel Aviv-bound foreign carriers such as Air India could operate over territory which El Al couldn't. There was a significant fare difference because of the routing in favor of the likes of Air India," he said.

"It wasn't until the Abraham Accords [of 2020] and the Saudi approval that it became partly possible for Israeli carriers to compete. The last stumbling block was Oman."

He expects the new routings to start "within the next few days."

In a statement, Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called it "a day of great news for Israeli aviation."

He added: "The Far East is not so far away and the skies are no longer the limit.

"We have worked to open the airspace, first over Saudi Arabia, and from 2018 when I visited Oman, to add Oman as well, so that we can fly directly to India and on to Australia. This was achieved today, after considerable effort, including in recent months. Here is good news - Israel is opening up to the east on an unprecedented scale."

Israel's Foreign Minister Eli Cohen also released a statement, calling the news "a historic decision that will shorten the road to Asia, lower costs for Israeli citizens and help Israeli airlines to be more competitive." He personally thanked the sultan of Oman, Haitham bin Tariq al-Said, for his "substantial help" in the process.

The announcement came after months of talks between the two countries.

It also follows an announcement earlier this month that El Al would start a frequent flier partnership with UAE carrier Etihad Airways. Frequent fliers can now collect and spend air miles across both airlines. The two had started codesharing on flights in 2021.

Last year, El Al said that a route from Tel Aviv to Melbourne, Australia, was in the works.
Summary: Oman is opening up its airspace to Iranian carriers, including Iran Air. Previously, the airlines had to fly a roundabout route to parts of Asia, adding hours to journey times.
Is the summary consistent with the document? First provide detailed reasoning, then answer "Yes" or "No".
Reasoning:
input_text.Response A:
The summary is not consistent with the document, which discusses the opening of Oman's airspace to all carriers that meet the requirements of the Authority for overflying, not to Iranian carriers specifically.
No
input_text.Response B: Yes, the summary is consistent with the document. The document mentions that Oman has opened its airspace to Iranian carriers, including Iran Air, which was previously banned from the airspace. The summary explains how this will shorten flight times and increase competitiveness of Israeli carriers. The document also mentions that frequent flier partnerships between El Al and Etihad Airways have been established, and that the two airlines have started codesharing on flights. Therefore, the summary accurately reflects the content of the document.

label_annotations.factors_a:
The 'no' cones at the end of the paragraph when it should come at the beginning.
Although the chatbot correctly states that the article talks about more than Oman opening, the brief is for news and the new thing is that Oman has opened too.
label_annotations.factors_b: Correctly puts the main answer first with subsidiary information afterwards.

input_text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to find a hidden unicode maker on your computer?
input_text.Response A:
Sure, I can help with that!  First you need to open a terminal window, which you can do by going to Applications -> Utilities -> Terminal.  In the terminal window, type the following command:
mkroman

This will create a new file called ‘mkroman’ in the directory that you are currently in.  Next, open the ‘mkroman’ file in your preferred text editor, such as TextEdit or Sublime Text.  You’ll see something like the following:

#!/bin/bash

echo -n "This is a Unicode arrow pointing to the upper right: "
echo -n "\u2192"

The first line is a “shebang” line that tells the computer what program to use to run the script.  The second line just prints a string, and the third line is the important one: it prints the unicode character that looks like an arrow pointing to the upper right.  You can replace the character on the third line with any other unicode character you’d like to print.  To save your changes, just close the file in your editor.  To run the script, you can double-click on the file, or type the following in a terminal window:
./mkroman

This will print the string with the unicode character that you specified in the file.  If you’d like to make this accessible from the keyboard, you can create an Automator application that runs the script, or you can create a keyboard shortcut that runs the script.  I hope
input_text.Response B: Sure, if you’re using an operating system like Windows 10, you can find the maker by going to the “My Computer” menu, then right-clicking on the “This PC” item, and then clicking on “Show All Files and Folders”.  This will open up a window that shows all the files and folders on your computer, including the ones that are hidden from you.  You can then click on the “Show Hidden Files and Folders” option in the “Show” menu to show all the hidden files and folders.  After that, you can click on the “Find” button to search for a file or folder that you’re looking for, and then click on the “Create” button to create a new file or folder.  If you’re not using Windows 10, you can search for “hidden files and folders” on your computer’s search engine, or you can go to the “File” menu in your computer’s operating system and click on the “Create” button to create a new file or folder.

Your client has asked you to write a product description using product features and product specification below. You are an amazing copy writer so please write a fun product description.

Product specification:
Barbie Fashion Night Looks - Pink and Black Cheetah by Mattel

Product features:
Each includes 2 fashions and trend-topping accessories
On-trend accessories include 2 amazing pairs of shoes (in different colors), statement pieces, and a handbag
Mix and match with other friends, fashions, and accessories (sold separately)
Dolls not included.
input_text.Response A:
Please write a fun product description
Fashionable and fierce, this Barbie Fashion Night Looks - Pink and Black Cheetah by Mattel is the perfect addition to your Barbie collection. With two stylish and trend-setting outfits, you can mix and match accessories for endless fun. The pink and black cheetah print dress is sure to turn heads while the black jumpsuit with pink detailing is perfect for a night out. Each set includes shoes, a statement piece, and a handbag. Mix and match with other friends and accessories (sold separately) for even more fun! Product does not include dolls.
input_text.Response B:
Barbie and her friends have full social calendars, so they're always on the lookout for the perfect look to paint the town pink. These fashion packs offer options for the fashion-forward friends to head out for a night of girl talk and girl fun! Each includes 2 fashions and trend-topping accessories. On-trend accessories include 2 amazing pairs of shoes (in different colors), statement pieces, and a handbag. Mix and match with other friends, fashions, and accessories (sold separately) to expand the possibilities! Fashions fit most Barbie dolls. Dolls not included. 
Product features are: 
*Each includes 2 fashions and trend-topping accessories
*On-trend accessories include 2 amazing pairs of shoes (in different colors), statement pieces, and a handbag
*Mix and match with other friends, fashions, and accessories (sold separately)
*Dolls not included.
*Ages 3 and up.

input_text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to find a hidden unicode maker on your computer?
input_text.Response A:
Sure, I can help with that!  First you need to open a terminal window, which you can do by going to Applications -> Utilities -> Terminal.  In the terminal window, type the following command:
mkroman

This will create a new file called ‘mkroman’ in the directory that you are currently in.  Next, open the ‘mkroman’ file in your preferred text editor, such as TextEdit or Sublime Text.  You’ll see something like the following:

#!/bin/bash

echo -n "This is a Unicode arrow pointing to the upper right: "
echo -n "\u2192"

The first line is a “shebang” line that tells the computer what program to use to run the script.  The second line just prints a string, and the third line is the important one: it prints the unicode character that looks like an arrow pointing to the upper right.  You can replace the character on the third line with any other unicode character you’d like to print.  To save your changes, just close the file in your editor.  To run the script, you can double-click on the file, or type the following in a terminal window:
./mkroman

This will print the string with the unicode character that you specified in the file.  If you’d like to make this accessible from the keyboard, you can create an Automator application that runs the script, or you can create a keyboard shortcut that runs the script.  I hope
input_text.Response B:
Go to "Start".
Type in what your code was.
Close out the unicode maker.
